intro: Spergula affinis, commonly known as common mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its small, rounded leaves and clusters of pink or white flowers. The plant typically thrives in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows, grasslands, and along stream banks. It is known for its ability to tolerate wet conditions and is sometimes used in ecological restoration projects. Spergula affinis plays a role in supporting local insect populations and can be an indicator species for certain soil types.
